This is NEWS & NOTES.
Late last April, in the early-morning darkness, a construction crew rolled up to the Battle of Liberty Place Monument in New Orleans.
The workers dismantle it, loaded it onto a truck and carted it away.
The scene would play out three more times over the next few weeks.
Three more statues came down from their pedestals.
New Orleans Mayor Mitch Landrieu marked the occasion.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
There is a difference you see between remembrance of history and the reverence of it.
For America, New Orleans, it has been a long and winding road marked by tragedy and triumph.
But we cannot be afraid of the truth.

Arizona, with Jim Pederson and Jon Kyl - that looks to me like a seat that the Democrats all of a sudden feel they might have a chance to win, because early voting there seems to be favoring Pederson.
Which is a huge surprise.
And that's why they're putting millions of dollars of ads in this weekend, to try to boost that.
Because everyone's thought, on the basis of early polls, that Kyl was on his way back to Washington.
And you've just left Pennsylvania, you're watching House races there.
And Pennsylvania is always thought of as a national bellwether.
What's the mood like there?
This is so interesting to me.
You've got three really hot races, Madeleine.
In the Sixth, you've got Jim Gerlach versus Lois Murphy.
They've run against each other before.
Gerlach is the incumbent Republican, but Murphy is mounting a terrific campaign.
And looks as if - it's too hard to call - but you'd have to say again, if you had to give someone the edge, it would be the Democrat Murphy, in that race.
In the Seventh, it's Curt Weldon and Joe Sestack.
And Weldon is a 10-term incumbent.
But the problem here is that he's been mired in lots of scandal.
And again, the Republicans have pulled money away from his campaign.
So it looks like they've given up on that seat.
And then, finally, you have in the Eighth Congressional District, the incumbent is Mike Fitzpatrick, a Republican, but he's being opposed by Patrick Murphy.
Murphy is an Iraqi war veteran.
And as you heard from both senators, Iraq is the issue, and Murphy has been hitting hard on this and saying that Fitzpatrick is simply a Bush supporter.
Bush has not been in the area.
Former President Clinton has been there to campaign for Patrick Murphy.
And it's all about the war in Pennsylvania.
And if the Democrats are able to win two of those three, that could for-sage a - presage, I should say - a good night on Tuesday for the Democrats.
And it seems to be all about the war, all across the country.
NPR senior correspondent Juan Williams and regular DAY TO DAY contributor, Juan Williams.
Thank you Juan.
You're welcome, Madeleine.
Stay with us on DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
This is DAY TO DAY, from NPR News.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
Have you heard about the enormous goal the U.N.
has set for itself: cut world poverty in half over the next nine years.
Africa is getting special attention and women there even more so.
They are among the poorest, although they produce three quarters of the continents food.
For her series Portraits of Poverty, NPR's Charlayne Hunter-Gault travels to the East African Nation of Tanzania.
CHARLAYNE HUNTER-GAULT reporting:

If you want to see the face of poverty, take a turn off the highway about an hour and a half outside of Tanzania's main port city, Darussalam and drive down a rocky dirt road that shakes up your insides as you roll over it.
Soon, you meet Ayesha.
Ayesha is 29 years old and sick.
She's also nursing her 23 day old baby girl, who's also sick.
AYESHA (Darussalam Resident) (Through translator): I'm just (unintelligible) progress, just sleeping and waking, and if I get things, I continue waking.
If not, I go back to sleep.
By things she means food and medicine, which sometimes neighbors help her obtain from a nearby tiny clinic.
But its cupboards are almost bare.

Most of the time Ayesha is bound to this house, just as she is locked into an endless cycle of poverty, and that keeps her bound to the kindness of neighbors, like the one who allowed her to stay in her small mud house, in a tiny dark room with a bed to sleep on and a leak in the ceiling.
(Foreign language spoken).
Ayesha tells a familiar story of a boyfriend who got her pregnant and is gone, leaving nothing behind but suffering.
(Foreign language spoken)
The rest of the story is also familiar in rural areas all over Africa, where 60 percent of woman live in absolute poverty.
(Foreign language spoken).
Like many poor woman on the continent, Ayesha's parents, now dead, were to poor to send her to school.
You keep in mind that in Africa the woman are not allowed to learn.
You will easily understand why they are poor.
Victoreen Keyanore Jetranew knows.
She is an African woman from Benin who's worked among poor African woman all over the continent through the U.K.
based non-governmental organization Action Aide.
Sanaboo Ali(ph) is a widow, also a face of poverty.
We find her at the back of a compound of mud brick houses, standing next to her own, beside a large wire enclosure that was once a chicken coop.
The chickens provided by a local NGO were supposed to throw her a lifeline to help provide for her children, twin boys and their three younger siblings.
But no sooner had the NGO left than the chickens died.
Sanaboo has no idea why.
MS. SANABOO ALI (Darussalam Resident): (Foreign language spoken)
Sanaboo tells me that there is a government program for one parent families.
It provides school uniforms, shoes and books.
But that doesn't put food on the table.
At this point all Sanaboo knows is...
MS. SANABOO ALI: (Foreign language spoken)
...you have to struggle.
(Soundbite of chopping)
Struggle means living with child like Doto(ph), who sits for hours digging a hole in the ground, putting in and taking out a rock, over and over again.
Struggle means not being able to afford to find out why he behaves as he does, or why he won't eat for days at a time, retarding his growth, leaving him smaller than his twin brother.
